concept.title: Step 2: Compile ACE SSL or use precompiled ACE SSL DLLs provided by Pivotal
concept.shortdesc: To build the ACE SSL, follow the steps that apply to your build environment. Or, use the precompiled ACE SSL DLLs provided in the native client distribution.

conbody.p: If you choose to compile the ACE SSL DLLs yourself, use the following procedures and make sure you provide the correct definition for LD_LIBRARY_PATH or PATH in . Otherwise, use the ACE_SSL.dll and ACE.6.1.0.dll files included with the native client under the <product_dir>/ssl_libs directory.

ol.li: Make sure the OpenSSL header file directory is in your compiler's include path, and that the correct version of OpenSSL libraries are in your library link/load path, LD_LIBRARY_PATH.

If you installed OpenSSL into a set of directories unknown by the compiler, set the SSL_ROOT environment variable to point to the top level directory of your OpenSSL distributionâ€”the parent directory to OpenSSL's include and lib directories.
Build ACE as described in the documentation provided on the page linked above. When building ACE, add ssl=1 to your make command line invocation, or add it to your platform_macros.GNU file.
Build the ACE_SSL library in the $ACE_ROOT/ace/SSL directory.
Set the SSL_ROOT environment variable to the location of the directory containing the OpenSSL inc32 and out32dll directories. Make sure the directories contain the correct version of OpenSSL.

Add ssl=1 to your MPC $ACE_ROOT/bin/MakeProjectCreator/config/default.features or $ACE_ROOT/local.features file, and re-run MPC to add support for building the ACE_SSL library to your MSVC++ workspaces and projects.
Open the ACE.sln solution, and refer to the ACE build and installation instructions provided in the link above for details on creating a config.h configuration header for this platform.
Add the following to config.h in the ACE compile: #define ACE_HAS_VERSIONED_NAMESPACE 1 #include "ace/config-win32.h"
Once the config.h file has been created, build the ACE_SSL project.
